glance_tempest_plugin/tests/rbac/v2/test.message: I think I'm missing why this is changing. You use project_client to refer to the same sort of thing below, so this seems wrong. What am I missing?
Yeah - that works. Since we don't consume system-scope yet, it's pretty easy to infer project-member.

Yeah - I don't have a good reason for this.

I was trying to think of a convention for a variable name that would shorten things up.

I felt that using `project_member` signified the returned client was a member of the project_id passed in. Whereas `project_client` is just a set of clients for a project *somewhere*. I don't think the initial protection test implementation used the terms consistently, so I was trying to fix that here.

It's a stretch. I'm open to renaming this or backing it out all together.
My use of `project_client` here is for a client that has no authoritative overlap with the persona client (self.persona, self.client, or project_member).
Same here, so I must be missing something.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: I think even some folks strongly in favor of type annotations will agree with me that, due to their awkward syntax, they make the code harder to read (even if they make it more comprehensible).  Anyway, be careful putting assertions like this in commit messages.  While they make the code easier to work with in your editor, they make it harder for others to read.

I dont't agree. Could you clarify what do you mean by awkward syntax? To me is seems more or less like common syntax in any other language. Is "self.jobdir: Optional[JobDir] = None" harder to read than "self.jobdir = None"? Seems to me in respect to the the conversation in the mailing list (http://lists.zuul-ci.org/pipermail/zuul-discuss/2021-February/thread.html#1504) that dropping this has no real base. I don't think that only my editor can benefit from type annotations. I fail to understand why someone would think that clarifying the type on declaration is a bad think.

tests/base.py.message: Based on our email thread, let's drop the variable annotations and stick to function signatures.

In this case we are setting instance level attributes where the type can't be inferred. I think the __init__ should be an exception to that rule as we are otherwise loosing a lot of the benefits of type annotations since the types can't be inferred automatically. This should mainly apply to optional attributes and values coming from opaque data structures.

Removed the driver specific code from the common file.

No - manila and cinder code bases are separate; and neither service has any dependency on the other. To share common code between the two services would require you to put this in a separate python library that the drivers can use. I would recommend against it, because downstream package maintainers will need to package that additional library.

This is related to our repository layout. Let me explain.

Zadara repository layout for openstack drivers is divided to contain
different drivers with all common objects across them inside the common file.
--->
  manila -> Directory for all the driver changes for manila service
  cinder -> Dir. for the driver changes for cinder service
  common.py -> The common objects that act as interface for zadara backend
---->
There will be some options that are not applicable for manila, but for cinder.
Can you please suggest if this is acceptable?

To clear, there are no dependencies introduced per se, between the manila and cinder services. The common code is the same, but the file is separately associated with each driver code bases.

The entire api's are completely common, expect for irrelevant options, which is similar to deprecated case. Please share your thoughts. Thanks.

What purpose would carrying unrelated code serve? If a method here is unnecessary/unused here, please remove it so it doesn't confuse reviewers and future maintainers. 

I would be strongly against adding unnecessary options - these options get generated into the configuration file and serve as documentation and would end up confusing deployes.

these two can be achieved with standard share type extra specifications: https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/admin/capabilities_and_extra_specs.html#share-type-common-capability-extra-specs-that-are-not-visible-to-end-users

Yes, they can be specified with share-type specs.

These are provided again here as an user privilege pointing the zadara backend share(dealing without standard manila). The user specifying these metadata properties on the share, overrides the default compress, dedupe configuration properties for zadara backend. Again, the idea is to be in a non-standard way intending the specific customers.

While this is an acceptable way to funnel share properties requested by end users to the backend, there are a few of things to keep in mind:

- metadata is used by end users for identification and tagging, and can be manipulated at any time. When metadata is manipulated, the backend share driver isn't invoked to make any modifications. 
- having to tag every share with these options will make for poor user experience? A fine alternative is to use share types and extra specifications. By default, operators/admins have permissions to create and manipulate share types and set up extra specs. So, they can create a bunch of share types with whatever combination of user related options that are necessary. Users can then use those share types to create as many shares as required. 
- manila can be configured with any number of homogenous/heterogenous backends; the place to put distinguishable information would be in share types since they influence scheduling

What are your thoughts on converting these into standard and scoped extra specs rather than share metadata?

The selected metadata options are the configurable parameters while creating zadara backend shares. The whole idea is to allow the customers to configure shares creations with backends without any layering from manila(not intervening any standard manila types,specs,scheduling etc). The validation is involved only during creation and is pointed for specific customers who are aware of the metadata and not expected to manipulate them.

> The selected metadata options are the configurable parameters while creating zadara backend shares. The whole idea is to allow the customers to configure shares creations with backends without any layering from manila(not intervening any standard manila types,specs,scheduling etc). The validation is involved only during creation and is pointed for specific customers who are aware of the metadata and not expected to manipulate them.

At the end, you are building a driver for specific customers but is providing it for the commnunity. All current and future customers will need to deal with this operational mode and admins won't be able to block users from manipulating lots of share's configurations. But, it is up to you to decide.

The "allow_access" and "deny_access" driver interfaces are deprecated, and are only left in code to provide compatibility with old drivers. Please implement the "update_access" interface instead - this allows for batch/bulk access rule changes to be committed by the share manager service: https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/src/commit/39efc2bde81c2a0c747a491d3a778b822ca263b8/manila/share/driver.py#L746-L836
Done

the ensure_share() interface was deprecated in favor of ensure_shares() interface: https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/src/commit/39efc2bde81c2a0c747a491d3a778b822ca263b8/manila/share/driver.py#L2762-L2787

The intent of this method is to update export locations if there was a network change in the backend.
The backend driver registers a valid state to manila's share manager via "get_backend_info" [1] and if this state is changed, the share manager invokes "ensure_shares" so that all share export locations can be updated in bulk. If you do not implement "ensure_shares()" and "get_backend_info()", service start up will be slow all the time, because ensure_share() is going to be called on _every_ share ever created on that particular backend, even when there is no need to update export locations. This is undesirable, so for scaling this, please implement "get_backend_info()"  and "ensure_shares()" so that the start up penalty can only be applied when something changes for real. You can include _any_ information you deem necessary - read from the backend or the configuration file in your "get_backend_info()" response. 

[1] get_backend_info: https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/src/commit/39efc2bde81c2a0c747a491d3a778b822ca263b8/manila/share/driver.py#L2742-L2760

I agree the penalty on services start-up and the advantage with get_backend_info().
But ensuring shares on every startup, covers all the cases that can't possibly incorporate as the parameters in backend_info. Since modifying any such parameters in the backend is not recommended and trading with slowness, it makes sense for me to read from the backend_info() response. Thanks.

Is this method idempotent?
i.e., if the access rule is added again, will it be ignored? or is an error raised?

I ask because you're not handling the case where add_rules and delete_rules are empty, and only "access_rules" is present. One instance where this happens is when a share is being migrated - the driver will be invoked to ensure that all the existing access rules are set to "readonly" instead of readwrite... https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/src/commit/39efc2bde81c2a0c747a491d3a778b822ca263b8/manila/share/driver.py#L761-L765

Submitted a bug to track the progress of share migration support for zadara driver.
https://bugs.launchpad.net/manila/+bug/1917980

Share migration is of two kinds: generic and driver optimized migration. Even when a driver does not support any optimized migration, manila's share and data services will work to provide a generic migration capability: https://docs.openstack.org/manila/latest/admin/shared-file-systems-share-migration.html

When performing a migration, the share driver is invoked to set all existing access rules to "readonly" instead of readwrite. When this happens, "add_rules" and "delete_rules" will be empty; and "access_rules" will contain all the rules you need to have on the backend. So, you must ensure that only the rules in "access_rules" exist on the backend with the correct access-level as specified within these rules. 

As discussed on IRC, if you're unable to test/support generic migration, please report a bug on launchpad so you can track that and get a fix after this initial driver patch has been merged.

Yes. For each access_rule, a server is created for provided ip(only supported access_type for zadara driver) in the backend. It will return the same(without error) if the access_rule request with same ip is received again.

Technically, the system-admin user will have the `admin`, `member`, and `reader` roles present in their tokens through keystone role implication feature [0].

This let's us simplify check strings if we want to:

  "get:foo": "rule:system_reader"

That will allow anyone with the `admin`, `member`, or `reader` roles on a the system to GET /foo.

We might be able to simplify this to: 

  "load-balancer:read-global": "rule:system_reader"

[0] http://paste.openstack.org/show/802831/

Yeah, this is a trade off. The "is_admin" is something we cooked up (a long time ago) to allow setting auth_strategy "noAuth" in our configuration file to disable keystone use. If noAuth is enabled, everyone is an "admin" in the eyes of the Octavia API.
It's used for testing and deployments that do not want keystone.
Historically we have honored it with the override files.

Oh, good call.

That makes sense with the NoAuth case now that you describe it. Another way I've seen projects deal with that is by short-circuiting calls to enforce() if CONF.auth_strategy == 'noauth'.

But I think either is fine.

nova/tests/functional/db/test_archive.py.message:
Sample update text:

This tests a scenario where archive_deleted_rows is run with
--max_rows and does not run to completion. That is, the archive is
stopped before all archivable records have been archived. Specifically, the problematic state is when a single instance becomes partially archived (example: 'instance_extra' record for one instance has been archived while its 'instances' record remains). Any access of the instance (example: listing deleted instances) that triggers the retrieval of a dependent record that has been archived away, results in undefined behavior that may raise an error.

We will force the system into a state where a single deleted instance is partially archived. We want to verify that we can, for example, successfully do a GET /servers/detail at any point between partial archive_deleted_rows runs without errors.

How do we reproduce this bug if we only create and delete a single server in this test?

From the above description I was assuming that we would have to create and delete at least two servers, archive one, try to get the other etc.
Ahhhhh right understood, I was missing the partial record part and assuming everything about an instance had gone.

Sorry for the confusion, I'll add more to the comment to explain it more clearly.

The bug occurs when we end up in a state where we've archived *part* of an instance (example: its 'instance_extra' record) and have not archived the entire instance (example: the 'instances' record remains). So to reproduce, we need to "split" one instance's records apart such that it has its 'instances' record present but its 'instance_extra' record has been archived away. Goal is to force access of a "partially" archived single instance.

nova/conf/scheduler.py.message: I'm sure there's a reason it's this high and not something lower that we are asking larger environments to raise but wow that's huge. Why would anyone ever need 1000 candidates during scheduling?

As we still have a split decision between placement and nova scheduler about the target host we have the edge case where the placement a_c query could return every compute host but the nova schedule (e.g. the NumaTopologyFilter or the PCIFilter) would filter out all but a couple of compute hosts from that result. So keep this low means potential NoValidHost results in an env where there are available resources to fulfill the boot request. 

Another reason to keep this number high is that placement returns more than one candidates per host (e.g. when there is multiple devices with bandwidth resource configured) then nova today simply use one of those candidates to filter the host. So asking for 100 candidate might mean we get info about 25 hosts (assuming 4 PFs with bandwidth on each host).
Can we reference the compute:servers:resize:cross_cell policy here or the docs under https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuration/cross-cell-resize.html somehow?

releasenotes/notes/bug-1870103-013e314e9.message:
We're trying to standardize the release notes to make them easier for operators to find info relevant to them.  So two comments about this release note:

(1) See https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/contributor/releasenotes.html#drivers for the format

(2) Write just one bullet point (or if you want to have multiple points about this fix, make it a sub-list).  Otherwise there's nothing connecting these two points.  For this fix, I suggest just a single point, something like:

  - |
    Pure storage driver `bug 1870103
    <https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1870103>`_: Ensure that
    the name used for an unmanaged volume does not exceed the maximum
    character length on allowed on FlashArray.

For future reference, you would do a sub-list like this:

  - |
    Bug info:

    * point one
    * point two
    * point three

You're doing this with the user's context. Is there a chance they could have passed the image get on L128, but aren't able to see the members here and thus get a Forbidden when they would otherwise have been able to do something?

Good question. I probably should have put some of the detail here into the comment, because this isn't very easy to understand.

This calls directly into the database layer for image membership [0]. The only thing the DB API does with the context object is tack on a couple of filters on to the SQL query if the user is *not* an admin [1]. So, the DB API will ask for all image members if the user making the request is an admin. Otherwise, membership will be filtered by the owner of the image and the members of an image, based on the context.

This is slightly different from other DB API behavior where we do stuff like:

  # somewhere in glance/db/sqlalchemy/*
  if not _is_image_visible(context, image)
      raise Forbidden(...)

If the image membership plumbing used that technique, we'd absolutely need to handle that case here. But as far as I can tell and my understanding of glance-DB-API-context-munging, I don't think it does.

I could be wrong, though.

I think in the worst case, this just comes back as an empty list.

Actually I made up is_member just as an example.

But okay, re-looking at this this morning I think I'm back on the same page. It is confusing to me to have policy rules with so many substitutable things in it, some of which happen in python ahead of time (i.e. f{foo} and %(foo)s) and some of which happen at policy eval time (i.e. an unmarked project_id or similar). So I was worried that if the admin wants to change the default they would need to put uuids in there in places where we do the substs. But, I realize now where I was missing the step.

> Isn't this going to require the operator to put actual tenant uuids into policy files?

The policy engine will substitute attributes from the target into the check string. We include this here because the new default policy uses:

  (role:reader and project_id:%(member_id)s)

So, if we were to call this API as project-members of project foo, where foo is the project ID, it would substitute in the following:

  (role:reader and $PROJECT_ID_FROM_CONTEXT:$MEMBER_ID_FROM_TARGET)
  (role:reader and foo:$MEMBER_ID_FROM_TARGET)
  (role:reader and foo:foo)

The second expression will evaluate to True since 'foo' == 'foo'. The roles from the context object get cycled through and matched against 'reader'.

Since we're building a valid target dictionary and the check string uses substitution, we don't require operators to update policy files, or match project IDs.

>  Wouldn't it be better to make this something like:

>  target['is_member'] = self.context.project_id in members
>

My point is that it is not a best practice to mock a same function multiple times at the same time. create_mocks() decorator starts mocking but it does not stop mocking. Thus, for example, there are three ACTIVE mock for api.keystone.tenant_list. Three parallel mocking happens and which mocking is used totally depends on the mock internal. This is required when this function is called using ceph orch apply -i <path>.
The idea is having the ability to apply the spec when apply: true, so this change is just a generic way to mount an additional volume containing the spec that should be applied.
If None, this mount will be skipped and all the other ansible modules can keep calling container_exec the same way.

Ok, that makes sense. 

Maybe we should keep keep changes to this minimal as possible in case we need to apply changes from [1] in the future, but I think the above change is justified.

You might want to add guits/dimitri to the reivew in case they have a useful comment on this. I wonder if this is a change they'd want in ceph-ansible itself. If not we keep this change as is but it could help to let them know.

ack, adding guits/dsavinea to the review it's a good idea.
Just to give you more context, these changes are used in [1].
[1] is an ansible module which implements the functions that are able to generate a section of the spec (passing the daemon and its parameters as input), and apply them against the existing Ceph cluster.
In [2] and [3] you can see an example of applying the daemon on a list of given hosts (the ceph_mon group).

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/773364/38/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/ceph_mkspec.py#146
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/773364/38/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/tasks/mds.yaml
[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/773364/38/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/tasks/rgw.yaml

NOTE:

The only allowed return values should be dict for two reasons:

1. we might want to register the result(s) and apply it later if 'apply' is 'FALSE'

2. less dependencies on the library that shouldn't take care about data
   structures conversion: we already import yaml in the ansible module and there's no
   reason to delegate the conversion to the translation layer which speaks only 'dict'
   language

EXAMPLE:

```
- name: Create the mds Daemon spec definition
  ceph_mkspec:
    service_type: mds
    service_name: mds
    service_id: mds
    state: present
    host_pattern: "*controller*"
  register: spc

- name: Persist the generated spec
  copy:
    dest: "/tmp/spec.yaml"
    content: "{{ spc.result | to_nice_yaml }}"
```

[stack@standalone cephadm]$ cat /tmp/spec.yaml
```
placement:
    host_pattern: '*controller*'
service_id: mds
service_name: mds.mds
service_type: mds
```

#. Optionally initialize a Ceph-based Persistent Storage Backend

There are two options for persistent storage backend: 1) the host-based Ceph solution and 2) the Rook container-based Ceph solution.

Could the workflow be arranged to support APPLY_TIME_IMMEDIATE, too. I think that should take precedence over APPLY_TIME_ON_RESET, because it would be faster since a reboot would not be needed.

Note the reference to those constants. That follows the pattern used by the Redfish BIOS hardware interface implementation: https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/e7d08bcf7544eab5518a88108dd35fcf7f7d2ddf/ironic/drivers/modules/redfish/bios.py#L179-L183. It appears sushy would need to be modified to support that pattern.
I am not familiar with the reasoning. A possibility is that "on reset" is considered more human friendly than 'OnReset'. It could be used in log messages and exceptions.

Without changing sushy, I agree it would not be feasible. And that may require deprecation. We would need to check with the core reviewers.

Is there anything else preventing us from adopting that pattern? The use of constants and mappings is used throughout sushy.

Regarding the constants: I'm not sure it's going to be feasible to use that pattern here. The supported_values field in OperationApplyTimeSupportField is simply a list field that returns the values in the list (e.g. ["Immediate", "OnReset"]), not a MappedListField that returns mapped values.
Thanks for the input. I'll investigate and update.

Yes, the pattern can be adopted if we add a new property to OperationApplyTimeSupportField() that returns the mapped list (and deprecate the original one if needed). And add a new keyword param for apply_time to the create_volume() and delete_volume() methods. And maybe some other changes that I haven't realized yet. But it is doable.

This mapping between, for example, "OnReset" and "on reset" within the sushy library confuses me. I don't understand the value or purpose of it.

I do understand the value of having a constant for these types of values. But it seems much simpler and straight forward to just set the constant to the schema-defined value, like:

APPLY_TIME_ON_RESET = 'OnReset'

My read of the documentation is that they should all be deleted. [1] While the specification does say much about this, it could be interpreted the same. [2] The idrac-wsman RAID hardware interface implementation deletes all RAID volumes and more.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/admin/raid.html
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs/src/branch/master/specs/approved/ironic-generic-raid-interface.rst
Thanks for the insight.

Where does it reset the system to apply the changes?

Related, looking around, this appears to be synchronous step. If system reset is necessary should it be async? I'm thinking, at least for iDRAC, there are 2 scenarios - real time and with reboot. Could ironic or sushy determine which is the case and behave based on that?

great, in both cases the request is still async, meaning it will take more than couple of seconds. On iDRAC creating a volume takes around 2 minutes, deleting around 1.5 minutes.

If not introducing async operations using Tasks&TaskService (at least for now), then need to increase sushy request timeout for these requests (currently 60s). I believe this shouldn't remain sync operation as it consumes a thread while waiting.

(Recently TaskService was added for Firmware update patch [1][2])

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/745950/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/749619/

Right. The plan is to support both scenarios. Will check the OperationApplyTime support and use Immediate if available, else fall back to OnReset. I have submitted a patch set for sushy that I'm waiting on to make related changes here.

And there will need to be code added in this module to handle doing the reset for the OnReset case (it just hasn't been done yet in this WIP).
copy-paste?
done

Have to check if something is returned.
Again for iDRAC, it is possible to submit a request, create a job, but job fails (Task's TaskStatus will be Critical with HTTP 200 response). From sushy code it appears that in that case None will be returned, from Ironic's point of view this is error.

Unfortunately, there are some bugs in iDRAC related to Volume creation in Redfish. Until they are fixed (currently estimated June 2021) and for those running older versions, would it be possible to add a hook here to try to handle error in idrac-redfish implementation? All the bugs found can be worked around by changing payload and resubmitting. These errors are returned in synchronous response when submitting Volume request (that is, not outcome of async Task).

Could add here a hook similar to post configuration that looks like this:

  def create_error_handler(self, task, exc, volume_collection, payload)

and expecting to return whatever volume_collection.create_volume() is returning (indicating success/failure) that is handled is `except` block - if error handler couldn't fix the error, then raising `RedfishError`, if error handler managed to work around it and submitted the request, no exception raised.
@Aija: Hook added. Please review and see if it meets your expectations.

There is a bug/missing feature in iDRAC for cases where physical disks are in non-RAID mode. In that case the volume creation will fail with error saying that some disks are not in correct state. In WS-MAN implementation physical disks are converted to RAID mode if needed.

There are no Redfish standard methods to convert to/from RAID, so one of the solutions for iDRAC could be that it converts that internally when receiving create Volume request. Still waiting from iDRAC team what their direction will be around this, but until this is fixed (that will take some time anyway), would it be possible to add here pre_create_configuration hook so that in idrac-redfish implementation OEM extensions are used to check and convert non-RAID physical disks? It could look like this:

  def pre_create_configuration(self, task, logical_disks_to_create)

Though have to think about how this will work with async operations (as converting will be long-ish running tasks).
@Aija: Hook added. Please review and see if it meets your expectations.

And at least for iDRAC can't issue these requests in parallel as each request creates a new iDRAC job and can't have more than 1 job per subsystem.

same applies to deleting - looping through and submitting all tasks async will not work with iDRAC as in iDRAC this will result in several jobs and there can be only 1 job per subsystem. It will submit first job that will start running and all the other will fail. In iDRAC UI this can be solved by adding all disks to pending operation and then in the end create 1 job to cover all disks, but there is nothing like that in Redfish. To get iDRAC work with Redfish would have to submit one job, wait till it finishes and then submit remaining 1 by 1 until done.

I don't know about other vendors, but would be useful to find it out.

The one that does not support, BOSS-S1, allows creating only 1 disk, so no looping.

If for some reason Immediate tasks can not remain 'sync' (e.g., they are running for too long), then need to return to this issue. Also need to find out if other vendors behave similarly or this is only iDRAC thing.

glance/common/wsgi.py.message: Do we really need separate 1000 thread greenlet pool for this?

This is moved from L511 to outside the conditional so that it's always set regardless of the worker size config. Also, it's reusing the same pool as we use for spinning up API workers so that all the existing thread spawning and accounting works.

Yes, you moved it from when there is 0 workers defined to create thread pool for the service to run, to always create that pool. The pool is only reused if we run glance-api without workers, otherwise each worker will spin up a pool for themselves. Thus I was asking if we really want to have this pool initialized just for this purpose as 0 workers is very rare case outside of CI.

Honestly I do not know which is better, to run in a dedicated proper thread or eventlet pool, there also should not be difference if it's 100 or 1000 greenthread pool as long as we don't spawn stuff in there. But this definitely does create an extra pool just for the single run cleanup in normal situations.

Just wanted to make sure this was intentional.

It was, and I opted for the common interface (which is what I meant by "same pool") instead of a random one-off thread spawn, which I think is fine. I'm quite sure it doesn't pre-allocate threads or anything like that.

glance/housekeeping.py.message:
This cleanup will work only if multiple backends are enabled, because this method returns path according to reserved store os_glance_staging_store

In case of single store we use node_staging_uri for staging the data.

I just realized that this morning when looking at a non-multistore job with my post-run test 😊

Will update this, thanks.
We should catch this somewhere.

I think that's already enforced in the store side too. But sure, I was more wondering if we really want to trip on it here should it be possible to slip invalid value through.

My initial thought was more on the line of catch it, log it, no-op as can't use it.

Note that this is just a config format check, and staging in general won't work if this is not set properly, thus there really can't be anything to clean up. It's also implicitly going to always be there if we're in multistore mode, because of get_dir_separator().

But sure, I'll dereference this somewhere in the main thread and force an exit if we hit it before we spawn the cleaner. Since the case below (where import isn't used at all) should still pass the check with the default "file:///tmp/staging" config, we can make this an early canary for an invalid staging scheme.
This should cover: 'deleted', 'pending_delete', 'killed' and probably 'deactivated' too. The last being up for debate.
Why? Checking deleted means we only run this cleanup once the record has been deleted (as in Image.deleted!=0 in the database), which should happen after all of these other cases, right?
Hmm-m, I mixed that with status, sorry. I think we even flip that switch when image goes to "pending_delete" status so it likely indeed covers at least the most important cases.
Ack

The only reason we would be getting this is because the staging directory does not exist (as it's looking to be set right per us getting something back from staging_store_path()). Empty folder would just return empty list. Definitely not an error we should just ignore (is the host missing a mount when the service came up for example). We should at least LOG.warning() here.

Like said, just log it instead of pretending that everything is fine and do nothing. I didn't say we should trip the service start over it, just indicate that we have found potential problem.

BTW due to the interop and defcore requirements at the time, your scenario 1 is not supported configuration so we really don't need to worry too much about it. There was clear requirement for at least one import option being avaiable, which in return puts clear requirement for staging being configured.

For 2. might happen once, yeii, it's not like we don't log anything less valueable across the services with constant spam. So having the service logging "Hey, couldn't access staging!" once during the lifecycle of the deployment for something that can be passed by "Yeah, we're getting to it." is really not that horrible thing, when if it gets logged again it might be actual issue that has gone otherwise unnoticed.

IMHO, it isn't our job to enforce that staging is present and working, just to not die if it's not there. The staging directory doesn't need to be present until/unless an actual image stage (or import that uses it) is initiated. So, the following completely legit scenarios would result in us finding a missing staging directory, where logging a warning would be invalid:

 1. I disable all import methods and have no staging directory at all
 2. My deployment tool is parallelizing the initial setup and we start the glance-api worker before we have created the staging directory (day 0), all of which happens before we even have a service catalog to find this endpoint.

Just like the must-probe-cinder-at-start-or-fail discussion we had, I don't think this should be overly concerned about a missing staging directory at startup. Its only purpose is to clean residue, if present, and if it's not there, there's clearly no residue. When we actually need a staging directory, that's where we should log a warning (really an error at that point) about it being missing.

This will catch all staged data from conversion and decompress plugins. Conversion writes to <image-id>.<target> target being the the string "name" of target format and decompression plugin writes to <image_id>".uc"
This condition catches those cases and leaves the data behind as ignored.

Those suffixes will ensure that this does *not* catch those things, as it will only pass if the filename is exactly an image uuid.

Or are you saying you'd like to not see the LOG.info() below for those items?
Okay, so you're asking to have those be cleaned up, gotcha.
We should not log fault conditions as Info https://docs.python.org/3/howto/logging.html#when-to-use-logging.

Is it a fault condition? If it is, then we should just nuke the files we find here (see note above). If someone mounts a dedicated filesystem here, we'll see things like "lost+found" and potentially other things like ".zfs" in that case. I definitely don't think we should always LOG.warn() on situations like this, and maybe LOG.info() is even too much.
I think this is our normal expected operation so Info or debug would be correct level here.
Done
Shouldn't this be a staticmethod?
Sure :)
Ditto

cmd/secret/decrypt/decrypt.go.message: why do you use separate package definition for each cmd? it's better to use secret

I am not sure if it is better to use the same secret pkg. Each of these sub commands has its own testdata/ and it also seems to be like this is pretty standard in the current project.

For example, you can see that the only existing sub command in secret right now, secret generate, is already in its own pkg.

you can just remove word 'secret' from variable name and there will be no necessity to add nolint directive [1]

[1] https://github.com/securego/gosec/blob/master/rules/hardcoded_credentials.go#L120
it looks more like examples of usage than long description. Please add it as cmd Example
this is not used here yet, so it could be just "_"
per command description, it looks like without specifying these flags command won't work. if this is true, I would mark them as required or make them as arguments.
all other examples are using the double hyphen --flag notation here. Let's change this for consistency

Does this mean that we overwrite the original secrets from version control? I would have expected that the secret gets printed to stdout, though I can see how there could be too many.

Maybe we could make this a required flag? We probably don't want to write decrypted secrets to a place that the user is not aware of. Especially in the git directory, as plaintext secrets could be committed by accident more easily.
This is technically required now, so the default value should never apply, right?

Actually, that was my first thought too, but cobra differentiates between "a flag not set" and a "flag value is empty" differently. For example, this is the output of this command when I run locally:

# did not set the dst flag
➜  airshipctl ✗ ./airshipctl secret encrypt --src testdata
required flag(s) "dst" not set

# setting the dst flag to empty
➜  airshipctl ✗ ./airshipctl secret encrypt --src testdata --dst ""
not implemented: secret encryption/decryption

So in the case, when an operator passes an empty flag, I was thinking it might be ok to assume the operator wants to encrypt/decrypt in place. But if you think otherwise, I can add a check to validate if it is empty and throw an error accordingly.

I think you meant required here, but I don't think we'll see this error during runtime.

Maybe we could just log err to stdout? It's odd that this Cobra function returns an error now. I see a lot of examples online where there is no return value.
Yeah, I realized we won't see an error during runtime. But unfortunately, we are needing a handle this error here to keep golint happy :)

cmd/secret/decrypt/decrypt_test.go.message: It's better to use separate package for testing, say decrypt_test or secret_test
will make this change as this seems to be a standard across the project. Although, this is not an idiomatic way of doing this in golang, is it? Any reason why we do this in airshipctl?

Following up here - either strategy could be considered as idiomatic Go, they simply represent different objectives. Testing in the same package performs white-box testing, where the tester has full access to the implementation, whereas testing from a different package performs black-box testing, and hides the implementation from the tester.

Tests in a separate _test package provide more realistic usage of the functions under test, so that is what we prefer for airshipctl
